9.3.17  11:23 pm   if I had a dollar for every time you said the word "saskatchewan" how much money would I have?

     zillions, if you count the times i have said it in my head. however if you only count the times i have said it out loud you might have zero or 1 dollar, i can't remember

9.3.17  11:14 pm   is it the question mark or the fact that something is being asked make a normal sentence into a question?

     in many languages and dialects (including the one you used in your question) 2 of the core words sometimes switch places when it's a question. but also an important factor is the plausibility that the thing is actually in question. additionally, if there is no question mark nor word reversal, often the presence of the word 'really/seriously/actually' can imply the question, if it is in conjunction with something that would plausibly be a question, in the context

9.3.17  10:45 pm   Hello, I am interested in learning music. I know the notes and octaves and staffs and voice ranges. But I don't know what exactly a chord is. And how are they played? When do you use them? And what is the difference between flats and sharps? When are they used? If you can, please tell me. Thank you so much!

     a chord is multiple notes at the same time. listen to any recorded song, and there is probably a 99% chance it has chords in it, unless it is just a singer with no accompaniment. how exactly to use them, well, i don't think there is any accurate way to explain it, but you can learn everything you ever need to know from experimentation. i'll give you a hint to get started, playing notes C, E, and G at the same time is called a C major chord, or often just called C. that should be more than enough to get started

9.3.17  10:44 pm   Why is the side of the coin without the head on it called "tails?"

     because sometimes there are tails on it, and the word 'tail' can also represent the other side of the body from the head, depending on what animal you're talking about, and depending on your willingness to say 'butt'

9.3.17  10:18 pm   Do you ever feel like despite trying to expand your horizons, your fans will, no matter what, rope you back into history videos?

     fans have never roped me into anything. in fact, they usually push me away from stuff. for example, history of japan was made during the time when the fans were only trying to 'rope' me into doing vines for the rest of my life, or 'shaving my piano, part 2'

     sure

     HOW?

     many ways. like for example, keeping me up to date on the latest memes and bits. like for example everyone has been asking about john cena and i have no idea who the heck that is. so trend briefings would in this case be useful

      that person would need to have your phone number or something to be in contact with you; 

     sure, or email

      but how are you going to tell that person that volunteer itself?...

     via email

      or perhaps it was just you "having a little fun on the questions page"?

In the recorded version (http://www.billwurtz.com/no-harm.mp3) you sing it without that rhythm. why?

9.3.17  2:36 pm   Hi Bill! I'm learning piano, and I really love that funky synth sound. But sometimes I have hard time figuring out certain chords I hear (maybe cause the notes of a chord played on a synth blend together more than a piano chord?)... But I was wondering if you can help me out with this. In this song, could you tell me the voicing for the chord that plays around the 1:44 right after 'just can't wait no more'?

     that's a closed Bmin7 voicing, but it might likely have been played as Amin7 and bent up, depending on whether the player prefers to pull down the bender first and bend up to the chord, or play the chord first lower and then raise the bender. so you could play G,A,C,E, and bend it up, or pull back the bender first and play A,B,D,F# and then bend it back to center. also important to mention that this tape is also running just a hair sharp

     Also those little chord hits that play around 2:44 right after 'baby I'm sure you would'? Here's the song. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LVSfnXeYmtQ 

     Amin6. very densely, possibly doubled in octaves, because there is definitely high A (880), but the F#(the 6 note) seems to be coming from more than an octave below. and in between you surely would have your C and E. it's just really dense and thick. also drenched in vibrato. it's Amin6, which means it includes notes A, C, E, F#. intuition tells me that this sound is automatically doubled an octave, and it's a one handed 5-note voicing with A on both ends. left hand would be working the bender/vibrato wheels

9.3.17  11:47 am   Can I use a tritone substitution irl? Like if I feel sad, can I substitute my sadness with a tritone?

     tritone substitution does not mean substituting something for a tritone. it means you keep the tritone the same, and switch the rest
